plist.p: Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Richemont's Half-Year Results Presentation. As normal, Sophie Cagnard, our Head of Investor Relations and myself will take you through the slides and we're joined today by our Chief Executive, Mr. Johann Rupert and our Deputy Chief Executive, Mr. Richard Lepeu who will, no doubt, take your questions after the presentation. Welcome to all of you in the hall and welcome to all of you in the – on the World Wide Web.

We've enjoyed solid growth in an uncertain environment in the first half. Equity markets continue to be weak as attention remains on the continued headwinds facing the world economies. Our main concern relates to the Eurozone, as well as the U.S. with growing recognition that de-leveraging will take place for years.

Prospects for growth are now questioned in the growth markets, prices of precious materials continue on an upward trend. Currencies have been adverse for most of the six-month period and volatility now we believe is a daily part of our lives.

Let's look at our financial highlights. Sales up by 29%, 36% at constant currencies. We had solid growth across all businesses and all regions. Retail continues to outperform wholesale, this is due to our NET-A-PORTER investment, our product creativity and the attractive stories that we have in desired locations.

Second, our increase in operating profit and operating margin. We achieved 25.5% in the first half of sales. This reflects strong pricing power of our Maisons, our manufacturing efficiencies and the operating leverage that we enjoy from our business model. Having said that, we did experience higher sales than we thought for the first half.

And finally, the responsiveness of our colleagues in a volatile environment to also helped our results. This was all achieved despite a 9% appreciation in the Swiss franc and higher precious material cost, which impacted gross margin negatively.
We did enjoy consistent cash flow from operations, achieving €606 million, this reflects our good results and the continuation of our short-term investment plans.

Let's go to the sales, first Europe, our number two region representing 36% of sales, of group sales. Europe achieved a 22% constant currency growth in total. Sales in Western Europe alone grew by 19% and it was primarily a reflection of organic growth, as few stores were opened in this region.

The sales growth was driven primarily by travelers, the increased weight of NET-A-PORTER in this region. However, all Maisons improved their sales versus a year ago period. Sales in Russia and the Middle East, grew at a stronger rate than Western Europe as a whole.

Let's move to Asia-Pacific. Asia-Pacific is now our number one region, representing 41% of group sales. The growth has been driven primarily by Mainland Chinese. China itself grew by 64% in the period. It is now our third largest territory after Hong Kong, and the U.S. and it represents 10% of group sales. We've had increased penetration in Mainland China through the selective expansion of our retail network. Our retail network in China now represents 323 stores. We've had broad-based growth across the region, however, Singapore, Taiwan and Korea performed equally well. Hong Kong, Macau and Mainland China were above the growth of those three markets.
From a channel perspective, retail was particularly buoyant, partially boosted by the opening of 43 stores including the internalization of external stores as well.

Let's turn to America. The growth was in line with last year, 35% in constant currency rates versus 37% last year. This growth was exceptionally believed despite challenging comps. The performance of Richemont in the United States reflects the quality of our operations, good execution of our distribution strategy and productivity gains in both networks. The growth in retail was primarily organic and the growth in wholesale was done with less partners but more partnership with those partners.

The performance was also augmented by much higher jewelry sales in the region, particularly at Van Cleef & Arpels. The high jewelry sales there were exceptional. Domestic tourism also helped in the U.S., more so domestic than international.

Moving on to Japan. Given it's lower growth rate, it's now our third largest region of the group. It represents 9% of group sales. It has shown remarkable resilience given the events that occurred in March. The growth was a function of bridal, the sales for Cartier and Van Cleef were exceptional. Van Cleef enjoyed strong High Jewellery sales and the specialist watchmakers performed well also. It doesn't change our view, however, that Japan is unlikely to register strong growth in the future.

Let's move to our sales by network. Retail sales enjoyed a particularly high momentum. Thanks to good performance at NET-A-PORTER and all of our Maisons boutiques. We expanded the retail network particularly in Asia-Pacific and we allocated our product to favor our directly owned stores. Wholesale growth was pretty broad based across all regions. Inventory levels remain at an extremely low level in the channel. The group generated 49% of its retail sales – of sales in its own network. This is positive for us from a supply chain perspective because we get faster feedback on the success or difficulty of our product launches.

Before I turn it over to Sophie, who's going to take you through the individual segments and Maison highlights, which I know you will enjoy, I want to give you the main points to focus on in the first half. We had record profitability for the Jewellery Maisons. We had commendable profitability for the specialist watchmakers. We had stable profitability at the Montblanc Maison. Fashion & Accessories is profitable and continues to improve. NET-A-PORTER enjoyed good sales momentum and was cash positive on an operating basis.
Now I'm going to turn it over to Sophie, to give you the details of the Maisons.
Okay, that's okay.

Good morning, we'll start with the Jewellery Maisons. Sales rose by a robust 34%, in line with last year. Operating contribution increased to €734 million, first leading to an operating contribution margin of 34%. Both Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels performed extremely well, breaking new records.

Cartier is as strong as ever, and Van Cleef & Arpels substantially improved its profitability over last year. As consistent with previous years, we expect for profitability for the whole year for the Jewellery Maisons to be lower than in H1.

Let's look at the main product in retail and wholesale developments within the Jewellery Maisons. First we'll start with Cartier, that enjoyed a broad-based double-digit growth in sales across geographies, product lines and channels. Bridal, Bijoux, High Jewellery, gold and jewelry watches were particularly successful with a special mention for Calibre watches and Ballon Bleu, Cartier's most successful watch line ever. The launch of the High Jewellery collection Sortilège was also very well received.

Strong retail sales for all product lines was supported by a dynamic and selective network. In this, Cartier continued to upgrade its distribution network with a net opening of four stores mostly in Asia-Pacific and the Middle East. At the end of September, there were 297 Cartier stores in the world, 37 of which in Mainland China. Cartier also carried out 17 major renovations. Its wholesale network was streamlined further.

Finally, this prestigious Maison benefited from impactful PR events such as the exhibition of the Cartier Time Art in Zurich, around Zurich, but very soon in Singapore, or the High Jewellery event in Rome for the unveiling of its Sortilège collection.

Next, let's have a look at Van Cleef & Arpels, which also enjoyed excellent growth in sales thanks to both its jewelry and watch offer. High Jewellery sales continued on a high note with the Voyages Extraordinaires collection as well as the recently introduced Bals de Légende collection.

Bijoux sales were driven by the Alhambra collection, but was further enriched with a Pink Vintage Pink Gold offer. Watches were boosted by the Charms Mini line. Van Cleef & Arpels further expanded its retail network, which now includes 87 boutiques.

Visibility and awareness were further enhanced with prestigious events such as the exhibition in New York at the Cooper Hewitt Museum of the high profile launch of a Bals de Légende High Jewellery collection at Buckingham Palace.

Here in the slide is the new ad campaign. Now, we'll look at our specialist watchmakers. All Maisons enjoyed excellent growth in sales. Our Maisons pricing power and operating leverage help mitigate the decline in gross margin resulting from strong Swiss franc and higher materials costs.

Remember that all components in our watches are made in Switzerland with the exception of Lange Zeitwerk, made in Germany. As a result, operating contribution rose to €312 million and the contribution margin reached 27% of sales, which is slightly below the 29% of sales of September 2010. We are pleased to tell you that Baume & Mercier's restructuring is progressing according to plan.

Let's look at the main product and network development of the watch Maisons over the past six months. Piaget's excellent performance was driven by retail in Asia-Pacific. In terms of product lines, Altiplano is more than ever (13:18) collection, confirming Piaget leadership in ultra-thin watches.

In jewelry, new models in the Limelight Garden Party collection launched a spectacular event in France, U.K., Germany and Korea, where very well received. (13:39) Bijoux were promoted by a strong digital campaign efficiently using social media such as Facebook or YouTube. This campaign features actress Jessica Alba as a new brand ambassador. The new advertising campaign targeted at Queensland was also introduced in September.

Finally, to raise further its profile, Piaget struck a partnership with the Third Beijing International Polo Open Tournament. Piaget's retail network was (14:13) with five openings, one in Macau, two in Hong Kong, one in Guangzhou and one in Paris Galeries Lafayette to reach 76 boutiques worldwide.

Now, let's look at Lange & Söhne. It enjoyed strong growth across all markets. These past years are meaningful Lange's expansion and striking complications with Richard Lange Tourbillon Pour le Mérite, Zeitwerk Striking Time and we redesigned and extended Saxonia collection. Lange & Söhne continued to upgrade its sales organization with strengthened local teams and a new boutique in Hong Kong.

If we now look at Officine Panerai, its solid growth in sales was the result of retail, Asia-Pacific and the sustained growth of the Manifattura Collection, which is a collection with in-house movements and high-tech material for cases, in particular the 3 Days Automatic Movement Family, which is a P.9000. Like the Luminor Marina 1953 Days Automatic, which is pictured here on the slide and models with ceramic and composite cases.

Officine Panerai continued its retail network expansions with openings in Milan and Nagoya whilst maintaining a very selective distribution for wholesale with around 500 external point of sale. Finally, its Diamond Space Exhibition in Shanghai generated excellent press coverage with over 250 VIP customers invited and 5,500 visitors in just two weeks.

Now let us move on to Baume & Mercier, that opened a new chapter in its history following last year's restructuring. The Maisons enjoyed robust sales, thanks to the success of a traditional Classima line and the regenerated Capeland and Linea collections. It also made important investments in communication to restore the image and awareness. The new brand concept "Seaside living in the Hamptons" was rolled out worldwide at point of sale (00:16:35) through the advertising campaign, e-marketing, e-communication and PR events. The promising welcome of a new collection from our partners, which are the retailers and media, and our end clients, lead us to target breakeven at contribution level for the full year.

Moving on to Vacheron Constantin, which show solid growth in sales, especially in Asia and North America, helped notably by the highly successful Patrimony line. Vacheron Constantin maintain a highly selective distribution policy while opening its first store in America, in New York on Madison Avenue, and serving less than 400 carefully selected external point of sales.

The Maisons also pursued investment in manufacturing to cope with mounting shortages. Finally, it opened its first Grand Heritage Exhibition, Treasures of Vacheron Constantin, a legacy of watch making since 1755. At the National Museum of Singapore, we've close to 200 timepieces exhibited. This exhibition attracted over 25,000 visitors.

Let's now turn to Jaeger-LeCoultre. The specialist watchmaker enjoyed a strong performance, which was driven by retail and strengthened partnership with wholesale. In terms of geography, Asia-Pacific, especially China and Hong Kong, outperformed. Switzerland, France and United Kingdom performed well. The period was marked by strong demand for classic timepieces among which Complication and Grande Complication, which have registered greatest demand.

Let me give you four example of successes; Grande Reverso Ultra-Thin Tribute to 1931, Duomètre à Quantième Lunaire, Memovox Tribute to Deep Sea and Master Grande Tradition à Grande Complication. Its retail network expanded to 41 boutiques, of which Hong Kong, Macau Galaxy, Mexico and St. Petersburg. Jaeger-LeCoultre expanded its manufacturing facility with an additional 8,000 square meter.

Now, IWC posted marked growth in all regions leading to record sales. This was partly driven by the re-launched Portofino line. To highlight its technical expertise, the specialist watchmaker introduced its new Portuguese Siderale Scafusia through a major press launch at the ESO Observatory in Chile. It further invested in retail. Its retail network now includes 36 boutiques – 38 boutiques, sorry.

Finally, Roger Dubuis. Roger Dubuis saw a commendable increase in sales, supported notably by the Excalibur Double Tourbillon Skeleton and the new Excalibur Lady collection. These models with diamonds are actually Roger Dubuis' bestselling models in the world. Roger Dubuis improved its market presence with two new boutiques in Macau and Singapore, and its visibility and durability, with a new Brand Ambassador, Scottish actor Gerard Butler.

We now turn to Montblanc, the Montblanc Maison. The 10% increase in sales was mainly driven by watches and leather, as well as by Asia-Pacific, Americas, and the Middle East. Retail and wholesale performed equally well, which is noteworthy given the tough comparatives for retail and the ongoing resizing and upgrading of the wholesale network, mostly affecting brand distribution. Operating contribution rose by 13% to reach 16%, which is the same margin as last year.

Let's look at the main developments at Montblanc. Montblanc's sales growth reflected sustained demand for leather goods and watches, in particular for the Nicolas Rieussec Chronograph and the Timewalker LL100, which are models with in-house movements.

The Montblanc Villeret Tourbillon Bi-Cylindrique was also acclaimed by collectors in (21:25). Sales of writing instruments was supported by limited editions and new creative concepts like the Tribute to the Mont Blanc. Montblanc's ongoing upgrade of its wholesale and retail network focuses on renovating or relocating existing stores, meaning the goal being to upgrade rather than to expand and on streamlining further its wholesale distribution.

Finally, Montblanc is raising its visibility and appeal with special events, such as the travelling exhibition in major cities celebrating the invention of the Chronograph by Nicolas Rieussec and the Culture Art Patronage Awards, which is now – are seen in 12 countries.

And now, we finally, the other business area, you remember that this segment comprises of Fashion & Accessories Maison, NET-A-PORTER and the facilities involving the manufacturing of components for watches for third parties and also for Maisons.

The Fashion & Accessories business generated a €23 million profit, up from the €7 million profit of last year. The performances of Alfred Dunhill and Chloé were particularly noteworthy, benefiting from strong operating leverage.

NET-A-PORTER recorded a €21 million operating loss. This can be attributed to the amortization and intangibles and higher investments in platforms, as well as to a less buoyant U.K. market. Growth in sales remained well above group rates. On an operating basis, it was cash generative.

Losses at the Group's watch component manufacturing activities were contained to similar level as last year. This was due to further investments in integration, mitigated by larger volume and improved know-how.

So we now look at Alfred Dunhill. It's enjoyed significant sales growth across markets and channels supported by leather with the Chassis & Bourdon collections and also supported by men's wear and was efficiently advertised in its Voice advertising campaign.

Alfred Dunhill continued to carefully expand its retail network now numbering 223 stores with the opening of (24:01) in Shanghai and KLCC, Kuala Lumpur. The deployment of ERP retail and merchandising system continues.

Let us move on to Lancel, which saw double-digit growth in sales across all channels. While consolidating for the success of the BB, Adjani, and Premier Flirt bags, Lancel launched Daligramme. Lancel also pursued investments in key markets and renovated the flagship stores in Paris in the Champs-Elysées, while opening another store – a new store in Moscow, Stolechnikov. It also set up direct operations in China. Great progress was made in deploying new IT systems, ERP, retail point of sale, and SAP to help sales grow further.

Chloé, the Maison posted double-digit sales growth fueled by Europe, Asia-Pacific, and leather. Handbag sales were supported by best-seller Paraty and Marcie and newcomer Madeleine. With the arrival of Clare Waight Keller as a new Maison designer, the reorganization of design, retail, and operations is now complete. The summer collection designed by Clare and presented last month was positively received.

Finally, NET-A-PORTER. It enjoyed strong sales growth well above group rates even without any physical presence in Asia yet. NET-A-PORTER from expanded and automated its U.K. platform and expanded its U.S. warehouse to face higher demand from NET-A-PORTER, the Outnet and MR PORTER. Regarding NET-A-PORTER, its main features during the period was the introduction of an interactive world map showing live our customer activity as well as the wish list alert.

It further enriches the offer by adding Dolce&Gabbana, Coach and Claudia Schiffer products, and raise this profile by launching a number of PR initiatives such as having Gwyneth Paltrow's website as a temporary affiliate or having a major full winter print campaign with major magazines. It now counts 560,000 Facebook fans.
The Outnet enjoyed positive strong growth while MR PORTER, which was launched in February, is growing nicely with high sales volume every day.
I will now hand over to Gary.

Thank you, Sophie. As always, you're much better at going through the Maisons' accomplishments than I am. Thank you very much. It's all up to me now to just take what Sophie has done and add it all up, so let's do that. Let's look at the operating profit first.

We had solid sales increases of 29%, 36% in constant currency. Our gross profit rose by 26%. We contained our underlying growth in operating expenses. All these activities led to an operating profit increase of 41% to €1.075 million. The operating margin achieved a record of 25.5% in the first half.

Let's dive in to the details of gross margin and expenses. As I said, gross margin rose by 26% to €2.7 billion. This represents 63.2% of sales. We did have 160 basis point decline versus the prior year. What is this a result of? We have the continued dilution effect of NET-A-PORTER, because as you know NET-A-PORTER is a different business model than our integrated brands. We had adverse foreign exchange affecting our sales. We had a stronger Swiss franc, would affected our costs. We had higher precious material costs on the stones and gold. And we also had higher component costs as well.

We tried to mitigate these factors generally by the pricing power of our Maisons. We enjoyed positive manufacturing efficiencies. And we also recorded a hedging gain of €70 million within the gross margin. I'll get – I'll discuss hedging a little further in the presentation.

Let's move on to expenses. Our expenses grew by 18% or 17% at constant currency, well below the sales growth. The ratio of our expenses were reduced to 38% of sales versus 42% a year ago. You'll see on the slide, we have a bridge from September of last year to September of this year. Let's go through that. NET-A-PORTER added 3% on the expense base primarily due to MR PORTER and expansion of the U.K. platform as Sophie mentioned. Remember MR PORTER did not start until the fourth – our fourth fiscal quarter of last year.

We opened up new boutiques, that added 7% to the expense base. We increased our communications spend in line with sales, that added 5% to the expense base. And all other expenses, which are selling and distribution without boutiques and administration, grew by 4%. And we enjoyed a foreign exchange benefit of 1%.

S&D costs in general were 56% of our total operating expenses. They rose by 17%. We opened up 43 new stores net, mostly in Asia-Pacific. Excluding boutiques and NET-A-PORTER, the underlying growth of S&D was 11% on a comparable basis.

Communication cost, as I said, up 29% in line with sales. The ratio is currently 8% of sales. As usual, we expect a larger spend in the second half due to Christmas, SIHH, Chinese New Year and we expect the yearly ratio to land somewhere between 10% and 10.5%. Administration costs were up 9%, but 7% on a constant currency basis. This underlines the efficiency of our business model and increased expansion of our activities in Asia.

Let's move on to net finance – sorry. Excuse me, one page over. Net profit now. Let's look at the items below operating profit. I'm going to deal with finance costs in the slide that follows. Our effective rate was 16.4%, generally in line to last year's full year rate of 16.7%.

For the year as a whole, we expect the rate to approximate 16.4%, between 16% and 17%, all elements being consistent with current conditions. As you know our tax rate can be somewhat volatile based on the exchange and our stock price and what have you.

We continue to expect a normalized tax rates for the medium term of 17% to 18%, due to much higher finance costs, which I'm going to get into in the next slide and the non-recurrence of last year's accounting gain related to the NET-A-PORTER acquisition, our profit for the year rose by 10% to 7 – net profit for the year rose by 10% to €709 million.

I wanted to provide for everyone, some detail on our net finance cost a little more than we have in the past. As normal, given the strength of the Swiss franc, we incurred non-cash losses on our cash related to mark-to-market adjustments. This amounted to €153 million in the period versus €119 million last year. I've broken that out separately for you.

And the second element is our hedging policy remains consistent. We hedged 70% of our cash flows in and out of Switzerland on a net basis. We've been consistent and we've been doing that for a number of years. What we have done, however, is changed the accounting for hedging. What we've – we did an analysis and what we've found is generally the hedges can be recycled six to nine months after the actual flows occur. And it wasn't really matching properly. So what we've decided to do is for all new contracts effective April 1 of this year, we will no longer apply hedge accounting to it. So what that means is the contracts are mark-to-market every month and any gain or loss is immediately taken into the P&L in finance cost. We will no longer defer the contracts in equity until they recycle a year later, okay.

What we've done there and you can see it on the slide is the effect of that change on all new contracts as of April 1 accounted for a €46-million charge. So what this means is going forward, we – the gross margin will be clean. And it won't take into account any hedging gains or loss. They'll all be recorded in finance costs. Now we expect the contracts booked prior to April 1 will be recycled by probably August of next year, okay. So we will continue to report for you the mark-to-market items here in net finance costs until the prior contracts recycle.

Moving on to cash flow, on par with last year, a result of increased inventory investments, higher receivables due to increased sales, increased gains from our hedging programs as I discussed, we recorded a €70 million gain in margin relating to the hedging. Our inventory rotation was reduced to 15.9 months versus 17.7 last year so inventories are a bit under stress, I would say. And accounts receivable continues to be positive. Our recovery rates actually improved over the high rates of last year.

Let's look at our fixed asset investments. Gross investments in property, plant and equipment rose 87% to €140 million or 3.3% of sales. We had increased investments in our manufacturing facilities. We had increased stores, new stores mostly in Asia-Pacific. And we expanded and automated our distribution platforms mostly associated with NET-A-PORTER in the U.K.

We will continue to roll out our investment program. We anticipate that fixed assets this year will rise to 7% to 8% of sales. We said in May, 6% to 7%, we have found some opportunities on the retail side and we expect that the fixed asset investment will be 7% to 8% this year.

Next, I want to get in to some detail for you on the fixed assets by category. 41% of the spend related to retail. The most notable retail projects were new Cartier stores in Hangzhou and Seoul and the renovation of the One Peking Road location in Hong Kong. Van Cleef established their third home in the Prince's Building in Hong Kong opened two months ago, Piaget opened up a store in Macau Galaxy, Jaegar introduced a new store in Hong Kong Heritage and Panerai opened up in Milan. And it should be noted as well that Vacheron Constantin opened their first retail boutique on Madison Avenue in New York. 31% of our total spend was from manufacturing and the remaining 28% relates to distribution platforms, IT and NET-A-PORTER.

Let's move to free cash flow. Total free cash inflow remained broadly in line with last year at €325 million. The higher cash flow from operation financed the higher investments in property, plant and equipment that you just saw and somewhat higher taxes. Let's take a snapshot of our balance sheet. After cash payment of €133 million in ordinary dividends in September, our net cash and investments position remained constant versus March of €2.6 billion.

Before we start with the Q&A, I just want to conclude. First, some color on October, the month of October. Constant currency sales were plus 26%, retail was plus 32% and wholesale plus 21%. The main drivers, I would say Japan continues to hold up. Asia-Pacific and the U.S. continue to outperform, retail continues to be strong thanks to NET-A-PORTER and our new stores. Europe however continues – or what we start to see in Europe is it's starting to be affected domestically by the deteriorating economic conditions, starting to be affected.
The traveling community, however, remained strong. But domestically, and in domestic locations, we're starting to see a bit of a slowdown.

Please don't extrapolate. This is my usual health warning. Please don't extrapolate these results into the second half. It's an uncertain environment. It's a volatile environment. Comparatives will be more difficult as we go through the year. We're starting to see the effect on a like-for-like basis on the overall growth rate but the growth remains strong, but just mechanically, we're starting to see lower sales on a comparative basis.
Foreign exchange, we have no idea where the foreign exchange is going to go. And remember as well, we'll spend more in the second half on communication.

Let me just conclude before the Q&A on our core strengths. We have a portfolio of prestigious Maisons, each with enormous potential. We have a leadership position in both the jewelry and high watchmaking segment. We believe there is significant potential for European high quality luxury products. We have broad exposure to clients, both from established and growth markets, thanks to our significant retail network.
We are, we believe, well prepared to face a highly volatile and nervous world because we have a strong balance sheet and a good cash position. We will continue to focus on profitable growth.

For the rest of the year, we face both the impact of global economic difficulties on the luxury goods industry and demanding comparative figures. Despite these challenges and based on our performance to date, we expect the operating profit for the full year to be significantly above last year.

Finally, the creativity of our Maisons, the responsiveness of our colleagues, the confidence in our business model and the strength of our balance sheet will enable us to continue to invest in our businesses for the long term despite the very worrying world economic environment.
Thank you. And now we will take your questions in the hall.
Stand up, please, and announce your name, your company name. Thank you.

Hi. Good morning. Helen Brand from Barclays Capital. Three questions, if I may. The first one relates to pricing. Can you talk about how much of the 36% organic growth in H1 relates to pricing and then the outlet for that into H2?
Secondly, if we could just talk about space growth in retail, how much space growth in retail do we see in H1 and, I guess, you talked about some opportunities in H2, what's the outlook there?

And then finally, I think it relates to that, but in terms of your selling and distribution expenses line, you saw significant leverage there in H1, what's the outlook for the leverage there in H2? Thank you.

On the pricing, it varies by brand by Maison, but for sure, we took price increases across the business in the first half. Those price increases have generally concluded now. We typically, despite the currencies, we wouldn't deal with pricing during the holiday season. We don't think that's appropriate. So from a margin perspective, I think, we expect the margin – all things being equal, we expect the margin to be flat for the second half versus now.
On the space, we said about 7% for the year. I gave you the store growth. We expect similar amounts of openings through the second half, I would say.

On the S&D side, we did have leverage in the first half. To be honest, we were surprised by that. I think sales were better than we expected. We tend to spend more in the second half. Please remember that if you go across the segments on a profitability basis, it's less in the second half. We expect it to be less in the second half. That's normal.
And I think if you're thinking about it and the way we think about is sales and S&D rise by similar levels in the second half. Okay?
Thank you.
Sure.
Sales and S&D rise by the similar. Whatever you're thinking about sales, we don't project sales. Sales and S&D rise in tandem for the second half.

Okay. I have a question just on the whole movement issue. Just wondering how well you guys are prepared next year for example we have saleta (45:32) saying their movements will already be going 25% next year versus this year. We have the whole Swatch Group counting movements and components. Is it an issue for you guys? Are you pretty comfortable that you have everything in place to be fully up and running next year or do you think there will be periods next year where there will be potentially you won't be able to meet demand? Or would you say you would be an overall winner from the situation?
Yes. Thank you.

Good morning, it's Will Hutchings from Goldman Sachs. I've got one sort of nearer term question and one longer-term question. One on inventories, which clearly are you alluded, Gary, they are very low in your retail network, I wonder if you can give us some color on what you think they're like in the wholesale network? And on a longer-term question, as the growth continues to be very strong and very robust across the world. How are you thinking about how that split in terms of deploying capital between capacity increases, investing in brands, and investing in distribution, how that will sort of play over the next two or three years?

Two or three years, maybe a long time for Goldman Sachs. It's a very, very short time in the let's say growth industry. I can't give you two or three years. No, I remember few have been question upon question about what are you going to do with Van Cleef? What are you going to do with Van Cleef? What are you going to do with Van Cleef? And we said that we'll take it and we'll nurture it. And that's quite a while ago. And today, it's doing extremely well. So, when we think medium to long term, we don't think two or three years we think five to 10 years, and obviously it's a balance between the type of capacity and the distribution systems. And you allocate capital accordingly. So – and your first question?
Yeah, I'll do that one.

What do we know about the. Suffice it to say, if you go and have a look at the discounts that trade partners give, it's down. Now, they would not be reluctant to give discounts to customers if they were flush with stock. So it's not like in the bad old days, we go there, offer you 20% before you ask. It's not out substantially. So from that we would – we have visibility, but I think that's the clearest. And we monitor the gray market actively. We have relationships with various companies with massive search engine capacity. So I think what do we do, Frederick's not here, but, yeah what do we do? Over 50 billion entrance a day. 50 billion, we have service actively looking.

So we'll see if product moves. Now, obviously, you do find currency influences if there are massive swings, then people will try to arbitrage. So I mean, our trade partners are not stupid, but from the retailer to the client, the discounts have narrowed substantially, I think, is that fair?
That's fair.

That we may have actually the productivity of distribution network, our own retail stores and our partners is improving dramatically. Actually, is they sell more with slight discount as mentioned in this offer, which means much better productivity and less cost of distribution, which may be a key for the future of our industry as well, to mitigate the increase of cost of manufacturings [indiscernible (50:08) and the cost precious materials.

And the way I look at that is I look at the receivables, right, and as I said, I mean receivables continue to be recovered at an extremely high level and for me that's an indication of the stock positions in the retailers. This time last year, we were about 90%, current, now we're at 92%, so I think the stock levels are fine.

Hello, it's Matthias Eifert from MainFirst. One question about, Mr. Rupert, you – when you took over the CEO job again. It sounds a bit like it's not a solution for the next 10 to 20 years. I would like to know what your plans, how long do you want to keep the job and is there any ideas about succession?
